questions.question: The value of pressure taken in the definition of permeability according to American Foundry Men Society (AFS) is:

explanations.a: According to the American Foundry Men Society (AFS) standards, the pressure used to define permeability is typically 10 g/cm2. Permeability in foundry sand testing refers to the ability of the sand to allow gases to pass through it under pressure. This standard pressure of 10 g/cm2 is commonly used in testing and evaluating the permeability of different types of foundry sands, including green sand, core sand, and raw sand.

questions.question: Permeability number depend on which of the following factors:

answers.a: Time for 2000 cc of air passed through the sand specimen

explanations.a: Time for a standard volume (typically 2000 cc) of air to pass through the sand specimen
explanations.b: Height of the sand specimen, as this affects the path length the air must travel through the sand.
explanations.c: Area of the sand specimen, which determines the cross-sectional area available for air flow.

questions.question: Permeability of moulding sand does not depend on which of the following facto:

explanations.a: Permeability of molding sand is primarily influenced by factors related to the sand itself and the molding process. the type or amount of molten metal poured into the mold does not affect the permeability of the molding sand. Permeability is primarily a property of the mold itself, determined by its composition and preparation, rather than the material that is poured into it.
explanations.b: Binders affect the compactability and porosity of the sand, thus influencing permeability.
explanations.c: The tighter or looser the sand is packed, the more or less space there is for air flow, affecting permeability.
explanations.d: The size of the sand grains impacts the porosity and the paths available for air flow, directly affecting permeability.

questions.question: Increase in clay content would result in:

explanations.a: Clay content in molding sand primarily acts as a binder. As the clay content increases the sand particles tend to stick together more strongly. This reduces the spaces (pores) between the sand particles. Decreased pore space means there are fewer pathways for air or gases to pass through the sand.
